comments.commentBody: I've been downloading and solving puzzles by the Patricks, Merrell and Berry. I'm happy to have another fine one to add to my collection.

We are lucky to be living in the era of the greatest closer of all time and having the privilege to watch him perform his craft. It's like living in the time of Beethoven or Mozart and having the chance to experience it live, not just hearing about it as a legend. Hats off to Trevor Hoffman for acknowledging it.

Four problems with the cloud, one simple solution. First, the problems:
1. Data usage caps = more monthly fees
2. Can't always get online
3. What if internet goes down?
4. Hackers!

Solution:
Don't put all your stuff on the cloud. Keep it on your computer, with a hard drive backup separate from your computer. Old fashioned, I know, but what's the downside? Back up some key stuff to the cloud, since redundancy is Rule 1.

Why put all your photos and videos and music in the cloud, anyway? When I look at my stuff, 90% of it is garbage. Or duplicates. Or things I'll never access again. I should just purge it. Yours too, I'll bet. The cloud is like having an ever-expanding junk room. We just keep more and more useless stuff. We'll end up paying extra to transfer and store it all.

Likewise with synching. I don't need to have all my vacation photos from 2005 instantly available on all my computers plus iPhone and iPad! I want to sync a handful of low-KB items like emails and database, plus most current docs and photos. Some but not all music.

If Apple stops making software for individual devices, I'll just go back to pencil and paper.

Tonight, the Big Man is on a Higher Stage.
But the spirit within his music remains with us,
strong, and fierce, and fine.
Well lived and well played, Clarence. Amen.
News that hurts this Heavy Trucker.

More than a sidekick, New York Times:

"That night we first stood together," said Springsteen of Clemons during his Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction speech in 1999, "I looked over at C and it looked like his head reached into the clouds. And I felt like a mere mortal scurrying upon the earth, you know. But he always lifted me up. Way, way, way up. Together we told a story of the possibilities of friendship, a story older than the ones that I was writing and a story I could never have told without him at my side."
Sad day. May your family be comforted by the numerous fans who also grieves along. Party on big man, party on.
First Danny, now Clarence....  Our hearts go out to you, Bruce! We feel your pain, we really do!
Baby,you were born to run.

My heart is shattered into a thousand pieces. I can't think of a Bruce Springsteen song without the magnificent sound of his beautiful saxophone. A gentle giant, a heart so big it burst. The losses suffered in the music and film industry over the past couple of years have been immeasurable, but this one hurts so much I am truly in pain, as if it was a family member. This is the music of my teenage years through now, middle age. As long as Bruce and the E Street Band kept going all was right with the world. Clarence, the world has been left a richer place for your being here. I will never hear the saxophone without thinking of you and your unbridled joy. RIP Big Man. My deepest sympathies to your family, your friends, and your fans throughout the world.

Thirty-one years ago I was partying with a group of new friends.  I was delighted when one of my favorites, Thunder Road, came on the stereo. This cute guy got out his saxaphone to play along with Clarence, note for note. I recognized the heart, the soul, the joy coming of his horn, lead by the great Big Man. Needless to say I married that guy and have happily enjoyed him playing along with Bruce and the Big Man for the last three decades.  Thanks for soul affirming music, Clarence.
He brought us all such joy!!!
There is Darkness on The Edge of Town tonight.

i've been booking concerts for the past 30 years, and one of the best i ever produced was performed by the big man. it was in l.a. in the mid '90's, clarence had his own band on tour, playing clubs. that night, he and his band were on fire the whole show, and the crowd was just crazy. then at encore, there was a huge roar from the crowd, and bruce walked on stage and joined the band. needless to say, it was an unforgetable moment for 500 fans in redondo beach. and a vivid memory for this old hippie.

rest in peace, clarence clemons. you played with heart and soul, and we all knew it.
The Big Man's joined another band. Play on.
the Big Man has been a huge part of my life for the last 41 years.  I will miss him and all that he added to the E Street Band! I send my love to his family and the band.

And in the end, the love you take
Is equal to the love you make.

Thank you for every note, Big Man....that's an awful lot of love you're taking with you.

Saw the Big Man skiing in Big Sky Montana once. He was under one of the lifts doing the bumps with that big frame of his. Slowly but surely he tackled the mountain. We yelled out from the chair lift above, 'Hey Clarence whooo whooo'....he stopped and said to his skiing partner...."They's my friends"

By Big Man.....:You, your music and your style will be missed.
RIP Big Man, you joy into my life. It was always a pleasure to see and hear you play up on stage.
One less boy on the corner, lazy and loose, doing the E Street shuffle. The music will never be the same. Thanks, Clarence.

The "Big Man" gave myself - and now my family - great joy for almost 40 years. There's no better legacy than that. I could listen to "Born to Run" and "Jungleland" (with the greatest sax solo in rock-and-roll history)over and over again.

Rest in peace Clarence - you will be missed
his "Peacemaker" album saw me through some dark times. RIP, sir.

I was working in a marina in Stamford, CT  when a friend who also worked there told me that she had gone out for drinks with Clarence when he sailed in on somebody's sailboat. I felt stupid because although I knew his music, I would ever have recognized him back then. I am 50 now, but I was 20 then, as was my friend. She was cooler, hipper, smarter than I was, and she said he was everything she'd hoped--just a really, cool, funny, smart guy. I can tell you, she was beautiful, and he was flirting with her, but never used his celebrity to cross the line. Her was a classy guy who played beautiful music. RIP, Clarence. You will be missed.
The sound we loved. What a guy.

AARP has always been geared to higher income retirees. Just look at their magazine. It talks about activities and places to retire that most people can't afford. I don't identify with it at all, but joined because their newsletter does have some interesting and informative things in it for people like me. I quit however, when they backed Medicare Part D. That plan is nothing but a scam and isn't much help at all. I got Medicare Part d because of mistake made on one of my prescriptions at the drug store. They charged me $93 for a generic cholesterol medication that really only cost $10. Before I found out the mistake, I joined. Now I am having a terrible time getting out of it. They have cheated and threatened me and I feel slapped in the face.
At one point they tried to charge me a $61 co-pay for meds that cost $11 out-of-pocket.

Now they want to cooperate with the conservative nitwits to lower Social Security benefits. If the Congress hadn't been robbing Social Security funds for years, there would be no problem. And why is everyone so scared of getting rid of the income limit? The whole system is rigged.

I am sick to death of our hypocritical government and organizations like AARP. We spend trillions of dollars on unnecessary wars and don't tax the rich and the corporations in any kind of progressive way. Everyone wants to finance the country off the backs of ordinary working people. I don't care what anybody says, we are a fascist state with no democracy left. Even Obama is a big letdown.
